Title: Economic and employment implications of fish farming in the Karaburun-Ildır Special Protection Area, Turkish Aegean Sea
Study species: Sea bass (Dicentrus labrax), Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata)
Study location: Karaburun-Ildır Bay Special Environmental Protection Area (SEPA) in İzmir Province
Impact details: Socio-economic impacts: Employment generation, community development, and local market dynamics
Study objectives: "The aim of this study is to analyze the socio-economic implications of aquaculture practices in the Karaburun-Ildır Bay SEPA. By examining the balance between aquaculture growth and ecological preservation, the study seeks to understand how these activities influence local livelihoods, economic opportunities, and the broader goals of sustainable regional development. This research explored the benefits and challenges associated with aquaculture expansion in the region, particularly in terms of its impact on local communities. The main hypothesis of this study is that aquaculture activities, fish feed factories, and processing-packaging industries within the Karaburun-Ildır Bay Special Environmental Protection Area have significant effects on the socio- economic structure of the local population"
Methodology for data collection: This study employed a mixed-method approach, using face-to-face surveys as the primary data collection tool to assess the socio-economic implications of aquaculture practices in the Karaburun-Ildır Bay Special Environmental Protection Area (SEPA). The surveys were conducted with key stakeholders involved in the regional aquaculture industry, including fish farms, fish processing facilities, and fish feed producers. A structured questionnaire was designed to gather both qualitative and quantitative data. In addition to the primary data obtained from the surveys regarding the businesses, secondary data were analyzed from Government Reports and Academic Literature.
Funder: Turkish Ministry of Environment, Urbanization and Climate Change (TMEUC)

Title: Exploring attitudes toward aquaculture in Norway – Is there a difference between the Norwegian general public and local communities where the industry is established?
Study location: Finnoy Minicipality
Farming system: Coastal Finfish aquaculture "respondents believe they have fish farms in their local area"
Impact details: Attitudes of National and Local public of a) how the local and the national samples differ (i) in their perception of how aquaculture may pose a threat to the marine environment, ii) in their perception of conflicting interests, and iii) in their perceptions of the aquaculture industry's potential job creation; and, b) how these perceptions (i, ii and iii) shape attitudes towards aquaculture.
Impact category: Social > Attitudes > Ecological impacts, Social > Attitudes > Socio-economic impacts, Social > Attitudes > General perceptions of aquaculture
Study objectives: "A comparison of attitudes towards aquaculture in Ireland and Norway suggests that Norwegians have more positive attitudes than their Irish counterparts, despite the intensity of aquaculture activities being much higher in Norway. Our study adds to this research by exploring the significance of living in a community where aquaculture is present. This is done by comparing attitudes in the Norwegian general public with attitudes of inhabitants of a small municipal area with a high level of aquaculture activity. Our research question is: How do people in a community where the industry dominates differ from the general population in their perception of aquaculture? Findings from this study will be important input for politicians and local administrations governing aquaculture."
Methodology for data collection: The data sets were obtained from two almost identical surveys, carried out as telephone interviews in two different samples. The first survey was a representative national survey conducted in Norway 2016. A survey company (Respons analyse) was used which had a panel of 40,000 persons over the age of 18 in Norway. Based on a quota sampling approach, participants were sampled strategically from the panel in order to achieve representativeness in terms of sex, age and geography. The total number of respondents was 1001. This data set is referred to as the national sample in the text. The second survey was conducted in 2017 in the municipality of Finnoey which has a total population of about 3000 persons. The survey included 100 respondents and this data set is referred to as the local sample in the text.
Funder: The Research Council of Norway (RCN), Research Program HAVBRUK2, grant #244269E40

Title: Large-Scale Aquaculture and Coastal Resource-Dependent Communities: Tradition in Transition on Chiloe Island, Chile
Study location: The large island of Chiloe. Located in the Tenth Region, 700 miles south of Chile’s capital city of Santiago. Research took place primarily in the town of Chonchi, located mid island on the eastern side.
Impact details: "Loss of access to traditional resources / shift from autonomous, subsistence-based livelihoods to wage labour / increased economic dependency on external institutions / privatisation and competition for marine space / cultural changes and erosion of traditional practice / social stratification and marginalisation / mixed employment impact"
Impact category: Social > Employment, Social > Traditional livelihoods, Social > Local economy, Social > Land and resource access, Social > Cultural practices, Social > Inequality
Study objectives: "The principal objective of this research is to evaluate how the ever-expanding aquaculture industry is affecting the sociocultural characteristics of coastal resource-dependent communities on the island of Chilo ́e"
Methodology for data collection: Used a combination of traditional ethnography, observational research, rapid assessment, secondary data analysis, and survey research. The includes structured interviews of 30-minute questionnaires circulated among fishermen and aquaculture employees (N = 277), formal interviews with 7 key informants over 11 months, and owners of aquaculture firms (N = 11), biologists (N = 4), academics (N = 7), and community leaders (N = 18). Interviews were recorded on paper, and later transcribed into a computer database. Using the Atlas TI software package, coded the text to find recurrent themes that set the foundation for the description of general trends through discovery of consensus in the data.

Title: Marine open cage aquaculture in the eastern Mediterranean Sea: a new trophic resource for bottlenose dolphins
Study species: Sea bass (Dicentrus labrax), Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata)
Study location: the inner Ionian Sea Archipelago, western Greece, an area, covering ~1020 km2 of sea surface.
Impact details: direct and indirect effects of anthropogenic pressures on marine mammals and the possible ecological consequences of their dynamics, specifically spatial trends in the distribution of bottlenose dolphins around fish farms and the trophic mechanisms behind this interaction
Impact category: Ecological > Marine mammals > Abundance, Ecological > Plankton > Productivity/biomass
Study objectives: "We developed an ecosystem model for the inner Ionian Sea Archipelago, western Greece, to: (1) evaluate the trophic interactions between bottlenose dolphins and their surrounding ecosystem, including cage-associated organisms; (2) investigate simultaneously 3 hypotheses that could explain bottlenose dolphin dynamics: (a) increasing fishing effort and changes in ocean productivity, (b) competition with other species, and (c) increase in number of fish farms; and (3) explore spatial trends in bottlenose dolphins distribution using the increased number of fish farms as an explanatory variable."
Methodology for data collection: Ecopath is a mass-balanced model that provides a static description of an ecosystem at a precise period in time (Christensen & Walters 2004, Christensen et al. 2008). It can describe principal species of auto- trophs and heterotrophs individually or by aggregating them into functional groups (species with a similar ecotrophic role), while incorporating data on biomass (t km−2), total food consumption rate (Q/B), total biological production rate (P/B), and diet composition (expressed as a fraction of prey in the average diet of a predator). Fishing activities can also be included by adding data on landings (t km −2), discards (t km−2), and bycatch (t km −2), as well as bioeconomic parameters (i.e. value and cost; Christensen et al. 2008)
Funder: National Science and Engineering Research Council of Canada and the Sea Around Us Project, a scientific cooperation between the University of British Columbia and the Pew Environment Group

Title: Reduced Lepeophtheirus salmonis larval abundance in a sea loch on the west coast of Scotland between 2002 and 2006
Study country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: Loch Shieldaig, Scotland
Impact details: Increased infection pressure of L. salmonis sea lice originating from fish farms and their effects on wild sea trout and salmon.
Study objectives: To investigate any associations between the densities and numbers of Lepeophtheirus salmonis larvae at the salmon farm during two different production cycles, and the larval lice recovered at the nearby wild stations.
Methodology for data collection: Methods included 1) Plankton surveys at 3 wild stations adjacent to fish farms; 2) Identification of larvae - Copepodids were identified to species using an inverted microscope; 3) Gravid Lepeophtheirus salmonis counts - conducted approximately weekly; the pens and fish sampled were selected at random; 4) Statistical analyses. The influence of station and time (production week) on nauplius and copepodid densities was investigated using Generalized Additive Models

Title: Attraction and avoidance of wild demersal fish and crustaceans to open-net aquaculture pens resolved by baited and towed underwater camera surveys
Study location: three study farms in Western Finnmark, northern Norway and four salmon farms in the Frøya region of central western Norway.
Impact details: aquaculture-related effects on demersal fish and crustaceans’ spatial dynamics and potential food web changes.
Impact category: Ecological > Wild fish > Community composition, Ecological > Wild fish > Abundance, Ecological > Crustacea > Community composition, Ecological > Crustacea > Abundance
Study objectives: "This study aims to address this by examining the effects of the presence of salmon aquaculture facilities and a particulate organic material enrichment gradient from farm wastes (uneaten food and faeces) on the spatial structure, density, and relative abundance of demersal fish and crustacean communities."
Methodology for data collection: A towed underwater camera (TUC) and BRUVs systems were used to record and count the relative diversity and density of demersal fish and crustaceans in the vicinity of the seven study farms. Sediment traps were deployed to collect suspended particulate matter along the enrichment gradient leading downstream of the farms and Benthic infaunal samples were collected with a grab from the cage edge up to 1.5 km downstream of each farm in the main current direction.
Funder: Norwegian Research Council under the projects ERA (grant number 228871) and SustainAqua (grant number 267829)

Title: Descriptive multi-agent epidemiology via molecular screening on Atlantic salmon farms in the northeast Pacific Ocean
Study location: British Columbia, Canada
Impact details: infectious agent exchange between wild and farmed fish
Study objectives: "We report findings from a multi-year, multi-infective-agent monitoring program, focused on farmed Atlantic salmon in Pacific Canada. This work forms part of a broader research effort using next-generation sequencing in pathogen discovery, followed by high-throughput genetic screening techniques, to monitor infective agents in multiple salmon populations. Here, we focus on results from a research-directed screening program, conducted at regular intervals on four Atlantic salmon farms throughout their production cycles. We characterise time series for dozens of infective agents, identify agents associated with mortality, and provide information for future epidemiological study."
Methodology for data collection: Four cohorts of farmed Atlantic salmon were sampled repeatedly throughout their marine production cycles, from ocean entry to the onset of harvest. Both live individuals, after euthanisation, and recently dead or dying individuals were sampled. Tissue from each sampled fish was genetically assayed for 47 different infectious agents (including viruses, bacteria, and metazoans). After field sampling and genetic workup, we fit descriptive statistical models to genetic prevalence and intensity time series for individual agents. We modelled temporal trends, calculated agent correlations and overall infection burdens, and looked for differences between live and dead/dying fish.
Funder: Pacific Salmon Foundation and Genome British Columbia

Title: Relative macrofaunal biomass reduced under an enriched salmon farm, Pelorus Sound, Aotearoa-New Zealand
Study location: on the western side of Crail Bay, Pelorus Sound, Aotearoa-New Zealand
Impact details: declines in macrofaunal diversity, biomass and productivity below the salmon farm
Impact category: Ecological > Benthos > Community composition, Ecological > Benthos > Productivity/biomass, Ecological > Benthos > Functional diversity, Ecological > Benthos > Abundance
Study objectives: The aim of this study was to describe the functional changes that macrofauna undergo beneath a finfish farm operating at a low-flow location in Pelorus Sound, A-NZ. We hypothesised i) that the macrofauna would respond to enrichment with reductions in diversity and abundance of larger species, with a switch to the dominance of smaller opportunistic species. We subsequently used macrofaunal size-based estimates of biomass to test hypothesis ii) that biomass would increase beneath the farm in response to enrichment.
Methodology for data collection: Sampling of Benthic organisms was carried out using a Van-Veen grab. Three replicate grab samples were collected at each of 9 sites. Samples were spread along the 15 m depth contour from north-east and south-west of Li 32 with four sites inside the salmon farm, and the remainder placed between long-line mussel farms. Distances of refence stations to nearest mussel and salmon farms were measured using Google Earth time-lapse imagery. A 20 mm core was also taken from the grab and subsampled down to 5 mm sediment depth for chemical analysis. Preserved infauna was sieved over a log-series of mesh sieves down to 0.5 mm and analysed for abundance. Wet sieving was used to measure Sediment characteristics and chemistry
Funder: New Zealand Ministry for Business and Innovation, NIWA Core Funds CEE1202, ACEE1305, ACEE1601

Title: Benthic macrofaunal biodiversity in relation to sediment sulfide concentration under salmon farms in southwestern New Brunswick, Bay of Fundy
Study location: Southwestern New Brunswick (SWNB), Bay of Fundy
Farming system: open cage, marine-based systems and multi-trophic aquaculture systems
Impact details: impacts on the benthic macrofaunal community as a result of organic enrichment due to salmon farms
Impact category: Ecological > Benthos > Community composition, Ecological > Benthos > Abundance
Study objectives: "The present study conducted intensive sampling of sediment sulfide and benthic biodiversity under two active salmon farms and one reference location in SWNB"
Methodology for data collection: Benthic sediment samples were collected under two marine salmon farms (sites A & B) and a reference site (C) in southwestern New Brunswick (SWNB), Bay of Fundy. Triplicate grab samples were taken at 6 stations at each site. Macrofaunal biodiversity and total free sulfide concentration were measured in each grab
Funder: Fisheries and Oceans Canada (DFO) Aquaculture Collaborative Research and Development Program (ACRDP), project MG-08-01-008, with contributions from the Atlantic Canada Fish Farmers Association and DFO Science

Title: AFLP and microsatellites as genetic tags to identify cultured gilthead seabream escapees: data from a simulated floating cage breaking event
Study location: Natural population in west Sardinia, and broodstocks in Italian Hatcheries
Impact details: to forecast the genetic impact of fish farm escapees of Atlantic and Mediterranean seabream hatchery
Study objectives: "In the present study, the breakdown of a virtual floating cage located in the west Sardinian coast was simulated and the resulting possible mixture between cultured and local wild fishes analysed. Two different case studies were simulated: in the first, the escapees were virtual offspring of parents from a distant geographical origin (east Atlantic broodstock), in the other they virtually originated from a Mediterranean broodstock. In both cases the reliability of AFLP and microsatellite markers for the identification of escapees among native fish was tested"
Methodology for data collection: Genetic fin clip sampling of wild and cultured seabream. 147 AFLP and 4 microsatellite markers were used as genetic tags from two different hatchery broodstocks (one of Atlantic and one of Mediterranean origin) and wild fishes from a natural population were fingerprinted. Putative offspring were computer-generated, and the confidence in the parentage assignment of their genetic profiles to the hatchery broodstock assessed. The virtual offspring were then mixed with specimens from a natural population to simulate an accidental escape from a floating cage.
Funder: MiPA (Act 41/82)

Title: A First Insight into the Microbial and Viral Communities of Comau Fjord—A Unique Human-Impacted Ecosystem in Patagonia (42° S)
Study location: the head of the Comau fjord located in Northern Patagonia
Impact details: Increased enrichment of microbial communities and with antibiotic resistance genes around salmon farms
Impact category: Ecological > Microbial > Diversity, Ecological > Microbial > Genetic diversity, Ecological > Microbial > Antibiotic resistance
Study objectives: "In this study, we hypothesized that the Comau Fjord viral and microbial communities will be distinct from those collected in global surveys, but they will bear the hallmarks of microbes from coastal and temperate regions. Particularly to this study, we also hypothesized that microbial communities will be functionally enriched in ARGs in general and in those related to salmon farming in particular."
Methodology for data collection: collected 40 L of water at 5 m below sea level sampling three surface coastal sites in the Comau Fjord and obtained metagenomes and viromes to test any taxonomic and functional diversity as compared to a global survey of the open ocean, from the Tara Oceans expedition. "We also compared our results against global databases such as IMG, NCBI’s RefSeq, and GOS to obtain taxonomic and biogeographical information and functionally analyzed the metagenomes regarding functions and their resistomes, as well as viral communities, which showed a certain degree of uniqueness in their protein content.
Funder: Agencia Nacional de Investigación y Desarrollo (ANID), “ANID-FONDECYT Regular 1200834”, ANID-FONDECYT postdoctoral 3210547, and by “ANID-PIA-Anillo INACH ACT192057”.

Title: Spatial and temporal changes in epibenthic communities at deep, hard bottom aquaculture sites in Newfoundland
Study location: Hermitage Bay and Fortune Bay, Newfoundland
Impact details: the influence of aquaculture on epibenthic community changes over deep rocky substrates
Impact category: Ecological > Benthos > Abundance, Ecological > Benthos > Community composition, Ecological > Epibenthos > Abundance, Ecological > Epibenthos > Community composition
Study objectives: This study explores spatio-temporal changes in epibenthic communities due to salmon aquaculture at deep (>30 m), hard-bottom dominated sites in Newfoundland (Canada).
Methodology for data collection: Characterized temporal and spatial patterns of epibenthic community composition during aquaculture production and fallow periods using drop camera surveys. Video monitoring performed 3–4 times a year over 15 months at two reference locations, two sites in production and two fallow sites. Distribution of individual benthic taxa was characterized according to depth, substrate type, temperature, sampling period and production state. Multivariate approaches were used to explore and compare the effects of time, distance to cage, as well as abiotic factors on benthic community structure, and examined whether intermediate stages of organic enrichment could be identified.
Funder: Aquaculture Collaborative Research and Development Program and the Program for Aquaculture Research and Regulation

Title: Potential ecological and economic impacts of sea lice from farmed salmon on wild salmon fisheries
Study species: Chum salmon (Oncorhynchus keta), Pink salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha)
Study location: Broughton Archipelago, a group of islands north of Johnstone Strait and off the northeast coast of Vancouver Island, British Columbia, specifically the Kingcome, Bond and Knight Inlets.
Impact details: The potential ecological and economic impacts of salmon farm-derived sea lice on wild pink and chum salmon
Impact category: Ecological > Pathogens > Sea lice, Ecological > Wild fish > Mortality
Study objectives: "The objective of this paper is to examine the potential ecological and economic effects associated with sea lice from salmon farms on wild salmon populations and fisheries. To address this objective, a bioeconomic model is developed incorporating sea lice induced mortality into an age-structured biological model. The pink and chum salmon fisheries in British Columbia will be used as case studies"
Methodology for data collection: A commonly-applied Pacific salmon population assessment method is the ‘run reconstruction’ model, which uses spatial and temporal catch and escapement data to estimate salmon run sizes at different times throughout the adult reproductive migration stage.
Funder: Canada's Research Network in Aquaculture (AquaNet)

Title: Demonstration of an impact of salmon farming on survival of wild salmonids in the North Atlantic and Pacific, using population dynamics data
Study species: Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar), Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha), Coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch)
Study country: Canada, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: British Columbia, Scotland, Ireland, Newfoundland, Bay of Fundy Canada, St Johns River Canada,
Impact details: Increased mortality of 5 species of wild anadromous salmonids in areas associated with increased salmon farm production
Study objectives: "The goal of this study was to "step-back" and look for evidence of an impact of salmon farming on wild populations by analyzing estimates of survival and run sizes over time in many stocks. The study was performed to test the hypothesis that salmon farming has had consistent and significant impacts on wild salmon populations through the North Atlantic and Pacific."
Methodology for data collection: Perfromed a a meta-analysis of population dynamics data studies and used an extended Ricker and mixed-effect Models to detect the effect of salmon farms on wild population survival.

Title: Participatory indicators of sustainability for the salmon industry: The case of Chile
Study location: Multiple communities where a significant percentage of the economically active population (EAP) is involved in salmon farming fisheries, across provinces Aysén, Chiloé, Llanquihue and Palena
Farming system: Not specified but assumed sea-pen farming
Impact details: societal issues in that salmon farming represents a use of marine resources distinct from traditional activities, that puts pressure on urban services and infrastructure, brings in new people and culture, and many times competes for labor or with the development of other economic activities such as tourism.
Impact category: Social > Attitudes > Ecological impacts, Social > Attitudes > Socio-economic impacts, Social > Attitudes > General perceptions of aquaculture
Study objectives: Constructing a set of indicators that respond to the perceptions of stakeholders in salmon farming and a common vision of long-term sustainability. In particular, a list of sustainable development indicators using a participatory methodology was developed for the first time for Chile.
Methodology for data collection: 1) A bottom-up approach to capture stakeholder concerns through workshops and and semi-structured interviews. 2) Development of 53 sustainable development indicators, 15 of them social, 19 economic and 19 environmental - developing a first list of indicators for the issues and areas identified gathered in the workshops with stakeholders, and then a top-down selection approach using the international literature. Integrating these two approaches resulted first in a long list of indicators and then, based on diverse criteria, a medium list.
Funder: project INNOVA-Chile 67854

Title: Vertical variability of wild fish assemblages around sea-cage fish farms: implications for management
Study species: Sea bass (Dicentrus labrax), Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata)
Study location: 3 fish farms (Altea, Campello & Guardamar) on the coast of Spain in the southwestern Mediterranean Sea, and 2 fish farms (Los Cristianos & San Andrés) located off Tenerife in the Canary Archipelago in the central east Atlantic.
Impact details: wild fish aggregations around farms which affect a variety of ecological attributes of associated wild fish, including: diet, condition, parasite loads, susceptibility to fishing pressure, and presence, abundance and residence in a particular area.
Study objectives: "we aimed to quantify fish assemblages on vertical (among depth strata) and horizontal (among sites) spatial scales of 10s of metres within fish farms during the morning feeding hours, when wild fish were most likely to consume lost feed. Further, we investigated similar fish farms in the southwest Mediterranean Sea and in the Canary Islands to determine if the observed patterns in fish assemblage structure were consistent among farms"
Methodology for data collection: Human divers performed counts of the following 3 times (3 separate days) at each farm over 2 months: 1) Measurements of physical variables in the 4 count strata (surface, cage, mid-water and bottom) with dive computer, and 2) Timed visual counts of fishes using stationary 1 min timed counts with the diver slowly revolving through 360° at different depths.
Funder: Spanish Ministry of Science grant MYCT-REN2003-00794 and ‘Canarias, por una Costa Viva’ framework (Ministerio de Medio Ambiente)

Title: Sea lice dispersion and salmon survival in relation to salmon farm activity in the Broughton Archipelago
Study location: throughout the Broughton Archipelago, British Columbia
Impact details: increased Sea lice infections and transmission to wild juvenile pink and chum migrating salmon
Study objectives: "We studied the distribution of sea lice in the Broughton Archipelago in 2007 in relation to salmon farming activity as well as the corresponding survival of wild juvenile pink and chum salmon"
Methodology for data collection: Plankton tows were made between 2 February and 2 April 2007 at 19 sites on at least two different dates and at different depths. Wild juvenile fish were collected with a beach-seine and examined for sea lice using the non-lethal sampling method.
Funder: Natural Science and Engineering Research Council of Canada, the National Geographic Society, the Canadian National Centre of Excellence Mathematics of Information Technology and Complex Systems (MITACS) program

Title: IBSEM: An individual-based atlantic salmon population model
Study location: river Os in Hordaland, western Norway
Impact details: introgression of escaped farmed salmon in native populations
Study objectives: "We developed an Individual-Based Salmon Eco-genetic Model (IBSEM) on the population dynamics in the river Os, in accordance with a long time-series of measurements in this river, to simulate the demographic and population genetic change of an Atlantic salmon population through its entire life-cycle. We assessed the sensitivity of the model in the face of assumptions made on the fitness differences between farm and wild salmon, and evaluated the role of straying as a buffering mechanism against the intrusion of farm genes into wild populations"
Methodology for data collection: "IBSEM is a new eco-genetic model for Atlantic salmon populations, which simulates both the demographic and evolutionary dynamics of the modelled population. Differences in origin (wild, farmed, or hybrid) are reflected in the genotype of the individuals and affect the growth, survival, and maturation. IBSEM is parameterized in relation to empirical data from a single Norwegian river that has been studied extensively for many years. Importantly however, the range of output variables is within the values reported for other salmon rivers, and as such the model can be easily applied to many other salmon populations."
Funder: Norwegian Research Council funded project INTERACT

Title: Wild salmon migration routes influence sea lice infestations: An agent-based model predicting farm-related infestations on juvenile salmon
Study location: Discovery Islands, British Columbia
Impact details: Transmission of sea lice from salmon farms to migrating juvenile wild salmon, more vulnerable than adults and may lead to a diminished number of adult salmon returning to their spawning grounds
Study objectives: In this study, we present results from an ABM simulating juvenile sockeye salmon migration through multiple fine-scale routes in the Discovery Islands, BC, Canada. These routes expose the salmon to larval lice originating from nearby salmon farms. Our model evaluates how different migration routes affect sea lice infestation rates on out-migrating wild juvenile salmon, offering a deeper insight into the dynamics of sea lice transmission.
Methodology for data collection: Developed a model framework, using comprehensive quantitative mapping of the coastline, to simulate wild salmon navigating different routes, and performed a sensitivity analysis on the influence of various migration-related parameters and proximity to salmon farms on the abundance of lice in wild salmon and the consequent impact on infestation levels by the end of their migration.
Funder: Aquaculture, Biotechnology and Aquatic Animal Health Science Branch at the Fisheries and Oceans Canada.

Title: The 2016 red tide crisis in southern Chile: Possible influence of the mass oceanic dumping of dead salmons
Study location: Chiloe Island and coastline
Impact details: Major socio-ecological crisis caused by mass dumping of 4,700t dead salmon from farms associated with a catastrophic second pulse toxic 'Red Tide', causing mass mortalities of bivalves, birds, other shellfish and macroalgae, as well as shellfish and salmon farm workers, divers and fishermen to lose their livelihoods and huge societal protests ensued.
Impact category: Ecological > Microbial > Abundance, Social > Local economy
Study objectives: In this work, we carefully analyze oceanographic patterns using satellite data, and, using a high resolution model, we simulate the transport of pollution from a location of a mass dumping of dead farmed salmon and its vicinity, to hypothesise whether this was responsible for the second pulse 'red tide' ecological disaster off the chilean coats in 2016. We discuss the major socio-ecological crisis and mis-management."
Methodology for data collection: Collected and analysed oceanic conditions during and after the dumping and using Lagrangian simulations we simulated the movement of pollution using MERCATOR model and ARIANE.
Funder: FONDECYT grant 3150587

Title: In situ infestation of sea trout Salmo trutta with salmon louse Lepeophtheirus salmonis reveals parasite-induced behavioral modifications
Study location: In the Runga watercourse, Straumfjord and Oksfjord areas of Fennoscandia
Impact details: Behavioural migration changes and mortality in wild Sea Trout (Salmo trutta) due to salmon louse infestation  burden from salmon farms
Study objectives: "We investigated the impacts of salmon lice on the behavior of first-time migrating sea trout by combining in situ infestation with acoustic telemetry. We expected that salmon louse infestation would have a negative impact on sea trout's tendency to make a final return to fresh water (i.e., survival), but increase their likelihood to return prematurely. We also hypothesized that salmon louse infestation would impact marine residency and habitat use, with exposed sea trout spending less time at sea and a greater proportion of their marine migration close to their natal river than unexposed individuals."
Methodology for data collection: Sea Trout capture using a non permanent fish trap and a fyke net tunnel, artificial and experimental infestation of lice in varying degrees of the caught fish, release and fish tagging with acoustic transmitters and deployed receivers deployed in the Fjord, in the river mouth and along the shorelines to study the migration of sea trout from the Runga watercourse.
Funder: Institute of Marine Research (IMR project 15696)

Title: Southern Chile, trout and salmon country: Invasion patterns and threats for native species
Study species: Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar), Coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch), Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha)
Study location: 11 large lakes and 105 streams, encompassing a total of 13 main hydrographic watersheds of southern Chile
Impact details: distribution and abundance patterns of invasive salmon from salmon farms and their potential effects on native fish abundance in lakes, causing threats to freshwater biodiversity
Impact category: Ecological > Wild fish > Abundance, Ecological > Escaped fish > Abundance
Study objectives: "The main purpose of our study is to asses the distribution and abundance of trout and salmon (thereafter referred as “salmonids”) and native fish in freshwater ecosystems of southern Chile. We proposed simple hypotheses such as: (a) patterns of invasions by salmonids should be related to human disturbances such as changes in land use (represented by native forest destruction) and water quality; (b) ecosystems with present salmon farming should have some of the new salmon species getting established as many escapes have been reported; (c) assuming that salmonids may have impacted native fish we could expect the latter to have better conservation status in watersheds with more pristine conditions.
Methodology for data collection: 11 large glacial lakes were sampled with Gillnets to capture fish in glacial lakes and then analysed and destroyed. 105 streams were sampled by wading along a portion of the stream with a “Smith and Root Model 12B” electro fishing equipment and by setting a seine net down stream, where the fish which escaped direct collection from electro fishing were then caught, identified and counted, used to describe geographical distribution and abundance of salmonids and native fish.
Funder: Lakes Region Government (Fondo Nacional de Desarrollo Regional), by the Fisheries Research Fund (Fondo de Investigación Pesquera 2000-25) and by the FONDECYT project 1020183, a contribution of the Forest Ecosystem Services Millennium (Iniciativa Científica Milenio Chile) project.

Title: Gill histopathology of wild marine fish in Tasmania: potential interactions with gill health of cultured Atlantic salmon, Salmo salar L
Study location: Tasmania, three Atlantic salmon farm sites and 3 reference sites: two estuarine sites: Hobart Wharf (20 km); Dodges Ferry (40 km); northern Tasmania, one estuarine site: Inspection Head (Tamar) (11 km); eastern Tasmania, two oceanic sites: Coles Bay (140 km) and St Helens (200 km)
Impact details: Infection prevalence and intensity of parasites of wild fish near salmon farm sites
Study objectives: "The aim of this study was to survey gill conditions of wild marine fish from several sites around Tasmania and to identify those conditions which may affect cultured species. Potential effects of farming on the gill parasites of wild fish were investigated by sampling both farm sites and reference sites"
Methodology for data collection: Wild fish were caught and checked for gill conditions using routine histology. Captured by angling around the sea-pens or at reference sites, or dip netted from the pens when the pens were crowded for bathing or harvest, or captured using a light trap consisting of a large, fine-mesh hoop-net, placed under a floodlight illuminating the surface of the water at night. Farmed salmon also caught and anaylsed.
Funder: a Fellowship from the Netherlands Ministry for Agriculture, Nature Management and Fisheries to BFN

Title: Seven year remediation study at the Carrie Bay Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) farm in the Broughton Archipelago, British Columbia, Canada
Study location: The Carrie Bay, Stolt Sea, salmon farm in the Broughton Archipelago of British Columbia
Impact details: The macrobenthic response and recovery of benthic habitats impacted by organic wastes from commercial salmon farms
Study objectives: An analysis of the Carrie Bay Salmon farm over 7yrs between peak production and following fallow periods to investigate the short-term recovery of benthic habitats impacted by organic wastes in comparison to other commercial salmon farms.
Methodology for data collection: Twelve benthic surveys over the last 7 years. A regression approach was used: video surveys; a 15 m depth current meter and a drifter study. Single sediment samples were collected along south bearing transects at 15 to 30 m intervals to a distance of 225 m and three replicate reference station samples were collected during most sample periods at hydrologically isolated locations >500 m from the farm. Three additional transects were examined in July 1999 to determine the extent of the farm’s effects and to confirm that the southern transect was most affected. Assessment methods at this site have included periodic video records coupled with physicochemical and infaunal biological surveys.

Title: Using simulated escape events to assess the annual numbers and destinies of escaped farmed Atlantic salmon of different life stages from farm sites in Norway
Study location: Release sites across the whole west coast of Norway from North to South.
Impact details: escaped farmed salmon represent a significant threat to the genetic integrity of wild populations
Study objectives: "The aim of this paper is twofold: (i) study the post-escape behaviour, spread, and recapture of Atlantic salmon post-smolts and adults released from different sites on the Norwegian coast; and (ii) by combining the information thus obtained with a new Monte-Carlo simulation method, assess the issue of unreported escapes by comparing the predicted numbers of escaped farmed salmon with the actual reports from Norwegian fish farms.
Methodology for data collection: Released post-smolt and adult fish were tagged with T-bar Anchor tags and/or acoutic tags in 3 experiments: 1) Recapture in four bagnets in Altafjord, tagging, and immediate re-release of recently escaped adult Atlantic salmon. 2) Acoustic tagging and release of farmed Atlantic salmon from netpens every year from 2005 to 2010, 3) Releases of out-of-season post-smolts reaered indoors and then released from netpens. Analysis of recapture data and Monte-Carlo simulations.
Funder: The Norwegian Ministry of Trade, Industry and Fisheries and the Institute of Marine Research in Bergen

Title: Behavioural responses in wild cod (Gadus morhua L.) exposed to fish holding water
Study location: A farm free area off Sørøya, and areas around Tromsø, Northern Norway
Impact details: Change in migratory behavioural responses in wild Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua L) exposed to water containing metabolites and waste from farmed salmon.
Study objectives: "If the asserted change in behaviour of migrating wild cod populations can be linked to establishment of salmon farms, water-soluble odorants are then likely candidates to explain such a connection. The present experiments were therefore conducted to test behavioural responses in wild Atlantic cod exposed to water containing metabolites and waste from farmed salmon."
Methodology for data collection: 13 sets of trials were conducted during different time periods;  1) wild migrating Atlantic cod from a farm free area, caught using purse seine by a local fishing vessel (migratory cod), 2) cod caught at approximately 100 m distance from a salmon fish farm, caught using fish pots (stationary cod), 3) 2yr old farmed cod, originating from a commercial cod hatchery. Each fish group trial were placed in a preference-chamber system consisting of three tanks and different (salmon effluent/feed) concentrations of treatment water experimentally flowed into a chamber to test reaction, movement and time spent  of the fish. in each chamber.
Funder: Norwegian Institute of Fisheries and Aquaculture Research (Fiskeriforskning)

Title: Mismatches in spatial scale of supply and demand and their consequences for local welfare in Scottish aquaculture
Study country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: Scotland’s Western Isles
Impact details: social and economic implications of scale mismatch between the nested global and local aquaculture systems
Study objectives: "This paper focuses on two scales: local salmon aquaculture in the WI (which is nested in a national context) and its relationship with the globalised industry. We aim to (i) identify and characterise scale mismatches in the Scottish aquaculture industry (using salmon farming in the WI of Scotland as a case study) and their effects on regional resilience; (ii) demonstrate the utility of a systems approach in analysis of scale mismatches for nested social–ecological systems; and (iii) examine the implications for future economic development with matched spatial scales."
Methodology for data collection: We applied the 'Driver Pressure State Impact Response (DPSIR) framework',  to salmon aquaculture in the WI to describe the economic, ecological, and social flow of effects, explicitly recognising local aquaculture as a nested subsystem within the wider global aquaculture industry.

Title: Densities of planktonic Lepeophtheirus salmonis before and after an Atlantic salmon farm relocation
Study country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: The Loch Torridon system on the northwest coast of Scotland, UK, with 3 fjordic basins; Lower Loch Torridon, Loch Shieldaig and Upper Loch Torridon.
Impact details: Affects of planktonic Lepeophtheirus salmonis larvae distribution and infection pressure due to Salmon farm relocation .
Study objectives: "The objective of the present study was to determine if, and how, the relocation of a farm affected the distribution of planktonic Lepeophtheirus salmonis larvae in the Loch Torridon management area. Given that Atlantic salmon farms have been found to be significant sources of larval lice in this study area, the removal of one of the farms could be expected to reduce the densities of larval lice at the site vacated by the farm"
Methodology for data collection: Between February 2004 and February 2008 plankton net sampling took place approximately fortnightly on the same day at 5 sampling stations. 2 production cycles were completed at each farm and some farms relocated to other farms. Samples identified for copepod and nauplii and tested for differences in mean density between cycles, in a parametric bootstrap approach.

Title: Ecology of Chilean dolphins and Peale's dolphins at Isla Chiloe, southern Chile
Study location: coastal waters of the eastern Archipiélago de Isla Chiloé in southern Chile
Impact details: changes in the occurrence and distribution patterns of Chilean dolphins and Peale’s dolphins due to the presence of intensive mariculture (Mussels and Salmon) activities.
Study objectives: "The study presented here examines the distribution patterns of small cetaceans in the coastal waters of the Chiloé Archipelago in southern Chile and outlines areas of concern due to spatial overlap with mariculture and other human activities"
Methodology for data collection: Boat-based sighting surveys, using determined or randomised transects, were conducted during consecutive austral summers and autumns, recording the position of sightings (GPS position and landmarks) at fixed 15-minute intervals and sighting conditions, species identity, group size (maximum, minimum, best estimates), presence of calves and neonates, a suite of environmental variables (e.g. depth, sea surface temperature), distance to the nearest mariculture structures (determined by laser range finder, < 1000 m) and initial behaviour.
Funder: E.B. Shane Award (2000) by the Society for Marine Mammalogy (USA), Kölner Gymnasial & Stiftungsfond (2000, Germany), annual grants from yaqu pacha (Germany) since 2002, the Russel Trust Award (2002) from the University of StAndrews (UK), BP Conservation Silver Award  (UK) for a joint project with F. Viddi (2002), Research Fellowship Award (2003) from the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS), and individual donations.

Title: The ecological limits of aquaculture: Comparative performance of salmon production systems
Study country: Norway, Chile, Canada, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: Global
Farming system: open net-pen, cage, Solid-sided, Flow-through, and recirculating aquaculture system (RAS)
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Semi-closed pens, Recirculating Aquaculture System (RAS)
Impact details: main ecological impacts of salmon farms that include escapes, organic and inorganic effluents, reliance on wild fish for feed, and increased pathogen loads
Study objectives: "To examine the relative ecological impact of alternative production systems. Here I explore alternative farming methods and provide guidance as to how pursuing different paths may impact the future limit of aquaculture. Here I ask: 1. Is the ecological impact per unit of production the same for all production systems? 2. Can a greater amount of farmed salmon be produced for the same level of impact in different production systems? H 0 1. Ecological performance does not differ significantly between the production systems. H 0 2. The quantity of farmed salmon will not differ significantly among the various production systems for the same level of impact.
Methodology for data collection: The Farm-Level Aquaculture Performance Index (FLAPI) tool attempts to translate the robust, quantitative assessments of the Global Aquaculture Performance Index (GAPI) and the Monterey Bay Aquarium Aquaculture Scoring Tool to the farm scale. By focusing in at the farm level the relative costs and benefits of different production systems can be assessed and contrasted to demonstrate how transitioning away from conventional net-pen production might result in a net ecological gains.
Funder: Pew Charitable Trust

Title: The role of community and company identities in the social license to operate for fin-fish farming
Study country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: The Isle of Lewis and Harris and the county of Argyll and Bute, Scotland
Impact details: crises of social acceptance and perceptions of salmon farming in local communities
Impact category: Social > Attitudes > General perceptions of aquaculture
Study objectives: "The current climate around Scottish fin-fish farming suggests a crises of social acceptance, ultimately questioning whether the industry has a SLO. This study takes an exploratory, qualitative approach to examining the dimensions of this crisis, using the SLO framework, in the geographical communities of Lewis & Harris and Argyll & Bute. The central question for this work is therefore, how is the fish farming industry perceived and experienced at a community level?"
Methodology for data collection: This research was conducted using a grounded theory approach. An inductive, thematic analysis methodology was applied to semi-structured interview response. Constructivist grounded theory is based upon inductive theoretical analyses of data, with data analysis and collection informing each other through the process.
Funder: European Social Fund and the Scottish Funding Council.

Title: Effects of ethoxyquin on metabolism and composition of active marine microbial communities
Study location: two coastal zones: (i) Achao, located in the inner sea of Chiloe, Los Lagos Region; 6 km (3.2 nm) from the closest salmon farm; and (ii) Coliumo Bay, located in south-central Chile, Biobío Region; 2 km (1.07 nm) from the coast - no salmon farms.
Impact details: effects of Ethoxyquin EQ (fish food additive) on the active microbial community metabolism and diversity, producing effects on the degradation of organic matter. Negatively impacted key naturally abundant groups such as Planktomarina and potentially key functional groups associated with nitrogen regeneration
Study objectives: " the objective of this study was to evaluate the metabolic response and composition changes of the active microbial plankton community when exposed to ethoxyquin"
Methodology for data collection: Water samples were collected using an oceanographic Niskin bottle at different depths at both sites. To assess the effects of EQ on the metabolism and composition of the active microbial community, microcosm experiments were conducted, adding three concentrations of EQ to samples.
Funder: the Interdisciplinary Center for Aquaculture Research (INCAR, FONDAP-ANID-Chile, Grants N◦15110027 and 1522A0004).

Title: Genetic analysis of infectious pancreatic necrosis virus from Scotland
Study country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: Across multiple areas of Scotland and the Shetlands isles in salmon farms and wild species.
Impact details: epidemiological links and prevalence of Infectious pancreatic necrosis virus (IPNV) interactions between wild and farmed fish susceptible to IPNV
Study objectives: "The aim of this study was to analyse the VP2 gene from 36 IPNV isolates from Scotland, to determine whether there are epidemiological links between IPNV isolates from farms, wild fish and the environment and to investigate potential wild and farmed fish interactions"
Methodology for data collection: IPVN isolate samples taken from multiple species in the wild and from farmed salmon. The Chinook salmon embryo (CHSE-214) cell line was used to propagate the virus, Phylogenetic analysis, VP2 gene sequencing performed, and DNA sequence analysis. 27 IPNV isolates were cultured, of these, 19 isolates were obtained from wild fish and farmed Atlantic salmon as part of an epidemiological study (Wallace et al. in press) and eight were historical isolates from 1979, 1999 and 2000 from FRS Marine Laboratory, Aberdeen, UK.

Title: Attraction of wild fish to sea-cage fish farms in the south-western Mediterranean Sea: Spatial and short-term temporal variability
Study species: Sea bass (Dicentrus labrax), Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata)
Study location: 300 km stretch of the Spanish coastline in the south-western Mediterranean Sea.
Impact details: impacts on the distribution, abundance  and interactions of wild fish species with fish farms
Study objectives: "In this study, we sought to determine if the abundance, biomass and species diversity of wild fish were greater around mixed Sparus aurata and Dicentrarchus labrax farms than at nearby open water control locations. Further, we investigated whether the assemblage composition of wild fishes associated with fish farms differed between locations separated by 100s of m to 100s of km and whether assemblages at farms were persistent for weeks to months."
Methodology for data collection: assemblages of fish were counted at each of 9 farms with rapid visual counts using SCUBA within each farm complex and at open water control sites 200 m distant from farms to measure abundance, biomass and number of species at farms and control sites.
Funder: the Unidad de Biologia Marina at the University of Alicante

Title: “Escapes” of Eggs from Farmed Cod Spawning in Net Pens: Recruitment to Wild Stocks
Study location: inner part of Heimarkspollen in Austevoll in western Norway and part of the adjacent area in the Fjiords outside.
Impact details: spawning and successive larval survival with subsequent genetic spread of farmed cod to wild cod stock populations, leading to the negative effects of interbreeding between farmed and wild salmon in terms of a significant reduction in overall fitness.
Study objectives: "In the present study, genetically marked cod have been raised as broodstock and represent a unique tool for tracing eggs/larvae in the wild environment back to farmed spawning cod in net pens. The fish from the 2003 brood were used in a pilot spawning experiment that aimed to determine the reproductive contribution of farmed fish in sea cages to a wild cod stock in a fjord system."
Methodology for data collection: A small net pen facility was established in the inner part of Heimarkspollen and stocked with genetically marked cod. Fish egg surveys were performed weekly thereafter. Collection and Identification of Eggs by vertical hauls of a Ju-day net and sampling of Cod Larvae across numerous stations in the Fjord. Genetic Identification of Cod Larvae of Farmed Origin performed from samples.

Title: Factors influencing return rate and marine residence duration in sea trout populations in Central Norway
Study location: three central Norwegian catchments (Fremstad, Sylte and Vatne) and their associated fjord systems (Trondheimsfjorden, Malmefjorden/Frænfjorden and Vatnefjorden–Midtfjorden/Romsdalsfjorden) in central Norway,  with varying salmon farming intensity.
Impact details: changes in Brown trout (Salmo trutta) migration behaviour due to salmon lice (Lepeophtheirus salmonis) infestations
Study objectives: "In the present study we used passive integrated transponder (PIT) technology to describe the variability in migration behaviour amongst three sea trout populations in central Norway. Specifically, we investigate the combined influences of L. salmonis infestation, out-migration date and fish size on (i) the likelihood of sea trout up-migrating to freshwater during the same year as out-migration and (ii) the marine residence duration during their first out-migration."
Methodology for data collection: Trout were captured over a 3 to 4-year period by a combination of fyke nets and electrofishing and fitted with a unique 12.5 mm PIT tag. Fish movements were detected using stationary bottom radio frequency identification full-duplex antenna. We estimated the mean lice infestation risk for each individual sea trout during their marine residence as a function of the weekly adult female L. salmonis abundance and farm production capacity.
Funder: the Miljødirektoratet (Miljødirektoratet), the Norwegian Institute for Nature Research, Fylkesmannen i Møreog Romsdal, Møre og Romsdal fylkeskommune, and Det Norske Veritas (to B.F.).

Title: Company level biodiversity impact assessment: An application to the aquaculture industry in Norway
Study location: 36 Salmon farms across the whole of west coast Norway, from North to South.
Impact details: Biodiversity impact of salmon farms, including; lice counts, escapes, diseases, lice treatments, and bottom condition.
Impact category: Ecological > Pathogens > Sea lice, Ecological > Escaped fish > Abundance, Ecological > Benthos > Functional diversity
Study objectives: "Despite a sizeable literature on environmental and biodiversity issues within the aquaculture industry as a whole, there is still a clear lack of studies that attempt tomeasure and identify company-level sustainability impacts and performance. In this paper, we fill this gap in the literature by developing an assessment tool that allows to compare individual Norwegian salmon farming companies based on their biodiversity impact during the marine growth phase of salmon when the most dynamic interactions with marine wildlife occur."
Methodology for data collection: Literature review to develop biodiversity impact indicators for salmon farming and chose escapes of farmed salmon, the effect of sea lice, diseases, medicinal usage concerning delousing treatments, and environmental impacts on the seabed in line with the literature studying biodiversity impacts of farmed salmon. We use publicly available data sets from the Directorate of Fisheries and the Norwegian Food Safety Authority of indicator data between 2016 - 2021 and created a multivariate clustering framework model to study the biodiversity footprint of aquaculture companies in Norway..

Title: Distribution and biological characteristics of escaped farmed salmon in a major subarctic wild salmon river: implications for monitoring
Study location: the area between 60 and 180 km from the mouth of the River Teno, the headwater rivers Inarijoki and Skiehtsamjohka form the 266 km long border between Finland and Norway, and the lowermost 59 km stretch of the River Teno runs in Norway only.
Impact details: Impact of escaped farm salmon on the wild populations as the probability to establish feral populations, competition for resources (food, space, mates), genetic introgression through interbreeding, and acting as vectors for harmful diseases and parasites.
Study objectives: "we analyzed the occurrence, distribution, and biological characteristics of escaped farmed salmon in a large salmon river in northernmost Finland and Norway, the River Teno, which supports a very large and genetically diverse wild salmon population complex. We also conducted a preliminary analysis of neutral genetic diversity and divergence in 17 microsatellite loci among wild and escaped farmed salmon and a farmed strain from a nearby aquaculture facility with a view to determining the prospects for future genetic identification of hybridization between wild and escaped individual."
Methodology for data collection: During the fishing season between 20 May and 31 August in 1985–2008, fishermen using various fishing gear collected scale samples from all their catches and off-season sampling included experimental fishing with drift nets over two weeks in late September in 1990 and 1991.  Trained fishermen recorded the total length (centimetres), weight (grams), sex, catch date, and fishing gear used. We performed microsatellite analyses on archived scale samples and extracted DNA from one to four scales per individual salmon using a commercial tissue extraction kit.
Funder: the Maj and Tor Nessling foundation and the Academy of Finland

Title: Influence of a massive aquaculture escape event on artisanal fisheries
Study species: Sea bass (Dicentrus labrax), Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata)
Study location: on La Palma, one of the western-most islands of the Canary archipelago, situated in the north-eastern part of the Central Atlantic.
Impact details: distribution and densities of escaped fish following mass escape event, and potential trophic interactions and spread of disease impacts
Impact category: Ecological > Escaped fish > Abundance, Ecological > Wild fish > Mortality
Study objectives: "The objectives of the present study were to investigate: (1) spatiotemporal patterns of escapee abundance in the wild; (2) the influence of a nearby marine protected area (MPA) on escaped fish abundance; and (3) the influence of escaped fish on local artisanal fisheries."
Methodology for data collection: to evaluate the distribution and densities of escapees in coastal habitats through 720 visual census, counted while snorkelling through transects of 100 9 5 m, at between 1 and 5 m depth and localities were randomly chosen at different distances from the escape point (from 0.6 to 60 km). Fisheries data were collected from the two professional fishers association, used to detect the influence of aquaculture escaped fish in artisanal fisheries.
Funder: a PhD fellowship from the Canary Island Government, cofinanced by the European Union (FEDER)

Title: Response of Hard-Bottom Macro-Zoobenthos to the Transition of a Mediterranean Mariculture Fish Plant (Mar Grande of Taranto, Ionian Sea) into an Integrated Multi-Trophic Aquaculture (IMTA) System
Study species: Sea bass (Dicentrus labrax), Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata)
Study location: Maricoltura Mar Grande (MMG) facility, situated along the southwest coast of Mar Grande of Taranto in the Northern Ionian Sea, southern Italy.
Impact details: changes in hard-bottom macro-zoobenthic assemblages and the environmental implications of Mariculture impact compared to IMTA (Integrated Multi-Trophic Aquaculture)
Study objectives: "This study aims to investigate the response of hard-bottom macro-zoobenthic communities to the conversion of a traditional mariculture plant into an IMTA system at the Maricoltura Mar Grande (MMG) site. By examining changes in hard-bottom macro-zoobenthic assemblages over a four-year period, this research provides critical insights into the environmental implications of transitioning to IMTA and its potential to enhance biodiversity and ecosystem sustainability in mariculture-impacted areas."
Methodology for data collection: The MMG plant was subdivided into two sectors: a treatment area (x2), equipped with bioremediators, and a control area (x2), without bioremediators. Each sampling site measured Environmental Parameters and Biological Sampling was collected by scuba divers using direct hand collection twice a year (winter and summer) from 2018 to 2020 in the four stations and during the summer 2021, for a total of 84 of samples. Abundance of macroinvertebrates was assessed using a qualitative scale, later converted into a numerical scale.
Funder: REMEDIA Life project (LIFE16 ENV/IT/000343) and by MASBIA project (Marine Sponges as Bioremediators in Integrated Aquaculture, an ERC SEEDS UNIBA cod. 2023-UNBACLE-0245506)

Title: Environmental risk assessment of non‐native salmonid escapes from net pens in the Chilean Patagonia
Study species: Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar), Coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch)
Study location: 1400 fish farming sites across 32 relevant water bodies (RWBs) in multiple districts in southern Chilean patagonia.
Impact details: environmental consequences of escapes of farmed individuals of Atlantic and Coho Salmon and Trout
Study objectives: "The expansion of salmonid farming in remote areas of Chilean Patagonia has raised concerns in the scientific community and society at large regarding impacts from escapes. Here, we attempt to address such concerns by performing a semi-quantitative risk assessment to describe the comparative likelihood and potential environmental consequences of escaped salmonid species in southern Chile based on available information and acknowledging uncertainties. The assessment can be specially relevant to inform more targeted monitoring and field evaluation of impacts, currently very weak."
Methodology for data collection: We estimate risks associated with each salmon or trout species based on a matrix of weighted scores that includes an evaluation of Hazard, Sensitivity, and Exposure. Our approach also considers risk components that might facilitate the survival and eventual establishment of salmonid populations. We base our analysis on a large review of existing scientific information, the expert assessment of the authors, as well as the identification of uncertainties.
Funder: the Interdisciplinary Centre for Aquaculture Research (FONDAP N15110027, ANID, Chile) and INVASAL (ANID – Millennium Science Initiative – NCN16_034). CBCA was supported by ANID FONDECYT initiation grant no. 11180897 and JAO was supported by the Chilean Doctoral Studies Fellowship (ANID – Becas Chile 72180095)

Title: The Opinions of Bc’s Public Fishers on Open Net-Pen Salmon Farms
Study location: Communities in and near Vancouver Island around salmon farming areas on the west coast of British Columbia.
Impact details: opinions, perspectives, and attitudes of experienced public fishers that relate to potential environmental and human health risks such as industrial pollutants introduced by the fish farms, destruction of wild fish habitat, ignoring of Indigenous land rights and ownership, Atlantic salmon escapes, disease and sea lice transfer to wild fish, and the use of antibiotics and other potentially harmful chemicals during the process of open net-pen fish cultivation. Causing serious emotional and psychosocial impacts to society.
Impact category: Social > Attitudes > General perceptions of aquaculture
Study objectives: "My research study collected information about the perceptions, beliefs, and opinions about open net-pen salmon aquaculture on BC’s coast from participants of the public fishery. The public fisheries, also known as the recreation or sport fisheries, “...are usually considered those where fishing is conducted by individuals for sport and leisure, with a possible secondary objective of catching fish for personal consumption. My research question is: To what extent, and if so, why are the members of the SFI opposed to open net-pen salmon aquaculture on BC’s coast?”
Methodology for data collection: "My sequential mixed-method research study used both an on-line survey and open-ended interviews (Creswell & Clark, 2011). Working with a purposeful sample of members from the Sport Fishing Institute of BC (SFI), my research study uncovered more about the reasons and motivations behind the organization’s public stance opposing open net-pen salmon farming on BC’s coast (Sport Fishing Institute, 2018). This is a mixed methods study working predominantly within the interpretive paradigm. The open-ended interview data was collected, analyzed, and developed through grounded theory practice."

Title: Between the devil and the deep blue sea: work safety for contractors in Norwegian fish farming
Study location: Online interview with 160 different organizations (fish farms) across west coast Norway
Impact details: occupational safety, high risks of injury and fatality of fish farm employees
Study objectives: "In this study, it will be investigated if there are special challenges related to safety and working conditions for contractors in Norwegian salmon farming. We will explore the following four hypotheses: H1: Compared to fixed employees, a greater proportion of contractors report work absence caused by work-related sickness or injuries during the last 12 months. H2: Compared to fixed employees, a greater proportion of contractors report having experienced near-accidents during the last 2 years. H3: Contractors report challenges related to trust, cooperation, procedures, and safety requirements in their work-related interaction with fish farming companies. H4: Compared to fixed employees, contractors report more work pressure that could compromise safety and report a higher prioritization of production at the expense of safety"
Methodology for data collection: a digital survey distributed to employees in salmon farming, including fish farm employees, operational managers, and vessel crews. 979 respondents employed by the fish farming companies (“fixed employees”) and 304 contractors.
Funder: Norwegian Seafood Research Fund under Grant number [901801]

Title: The effect of exposure to farmed salmon on piscine orthoreovirus infection and fitness in wild Pacific salmon in British Columbia, Canada
Study location: fish markets and multiple wild watershed migration areas along west coast BC, in varying distances from salmon farms.
Impact details: PRV (piscine orthoreovirus virus) infection rates of wild salmon contracted from fish farmed salmon, implications of reduced fitness in wild salmon impacting their survival and reproduction.
Study objectives: "Here, we report the results of PRV screening of a broad collection of wild salmonids sampled throughout much of BC in 2012 and 2013, and samples of farmed Atlantic salmon and steelhead reared in BC net pen facilities from the same time period. We assess these data for evidence of (i) a potential epidemiological link between farmed and wild salmon and (ii) potential impact of PRV infection on wild fish. In addition, we also present data, sampled from Oweekeno Lake between 2014 and 2016, on PRV infection status of wild salmonids including an endangered sockeye salmon population"
Methodology for data collection: gill, heart, head kidney, and spleen tissues were extracted from 262 fresh farmed BC Atlantic salmon purchased from 10 BC market chains in BC, and 601 wild Pacific salmonids collected from marine, obtained from weekly beach seines, and freshwater, through fixed trap nets, purse seining, and surface trawling, from a number of Regions. Another 402 salmonids were sampled from Oweekeno Lake in a separate year and so were analyzed separately. Multiple regions were sampled with varying distances to fish farms. Samples were measured with viral screening techniques and exposure to salmon farms.
Funder: NSERC Discovery Grant, The Jaymac Foundation, Patagonia, The Tides Foundation, The Vancouver Foundation, Vancity Credit Union and many smaller donors

Title: Inferring Atlantic salmon post-smolt migration patterns using genetic assignment
Study location: Multiple river tributaries of Hardangerfjord, Southern Norway
Impact details: high infestations of salmon lice on seaward migrating salmon post-smolts resulting in sea-lice-mediated mortality due to spatio-temporal overlap and migration length between sea lice and post-smolts in the fjords.
Impact category: Ecological > Pathogens > Sea lice, Ecological > Wild fish > Mortality
Study objectives: "Here, we developed a genetic baseline representing all the significant Atlantic salmon populations in the Hardangerfjord, a farming intense region in western Norway where sea-lice-induced mortality has been reported to be high, to identify the river or region of origin of post-smolts caught in the annual sea lice trawl surveys in the period 2013–2017. Our overall aim was to investigate the potential of identifying post-smolts back to river or region of origin using MSA, and thereafter, to investigate spatial and temporal patterns of post-smolt migration in this fjord"
Methodology for data collection: 2011 to 2018 Sampling fish (364 individuals from 14 rivers) in rivers (establishing the genetic baseline), originated from 1) scale / tissue samples donated by anglers or by other research institutions or environmental consultancies, 2) existing data and tissue samples from Institute of Marine Research (IMR), 3) samples collected by electrofishing. Also Sampling post-smolts in the sea (trawl samples) from 2013 to 2017 and were sedated, examined for sea lice, measured (wet weight, total and fork length). DNA analysis and Mixed stock analysis (MSA) of all samples was conducted.
Funder: Norwegian Ministry of Trade, Industry and Fisheries

Title: Dysbiosis in marine aquaculture revealed through microbiome analysis: reverse ecology for environmental sustainability
Study location: close to the coast of Guardamar del Segura (Alicante, Spain)
Impact details: changes in the water column microbiome and how they lead to counteracting the excess nutrients (and pollutants) in mariculture
Study objectives: "This study aimed to examine the changes within the microbial population in the water column associated with mariculture (i.e mariculture microbiome) as well as to provide an understanding of their ecological implications. Here, in order to analyse these changes, we compared water samples from two depths on marine farms of gilthead seabream cultures against pristine waters collected at different depths from an offshore location"
Methodology for data collection: Sediment / water samples collected inside and below sea pen, then sequencing, assembly and annotation of metagenomic samples measured and performed comparison between mariculture and pristine offshore waters metagenomic samples.
Funder: Spanish Ministerio de Econom ́ıa y Competitividad, the Generalitat Valenciana, the Burnett School of Biomedical Sciences at the University of Central Florida

Title: Coho salmon productivity in relation to salmon lice from infected prey and salmon farms
Study location: 53 watersheds in four management areas in the midcoast of British Columbia, including Broughton Archipelago.
Impact details: Relative to unexposed populations, coho salmon productivity in an area of intensive salmon aquaculture was depressed approximately sevenfold during a period of salmon louse infestations
Impact category: Ecological > Pathogens > Sea lice, Ecological > Wild fish > Mortality
Study objectives: "Here, we examine time series data on coho salmon populations from the central coast of British Columbia that have varied in their exposure to salmon louse infestations associated with salmon aquaculture. We compared coho productivity (recruits per spawner at low spawner abundance) between populations exposed and unexposed to salmon farms, both before and during louse infestations."
Methodology for data collection: We compiled Fisheries and Oceans Canada escapement data from 1975 to 2007, and estimated exploitation rates based on coded-wire tags placed in out-migrating smolts and recovered by fisheries as adults return to their natal watersheds from 1975 to 1998. We used a hierarchical model of stock-recruit dynamics to compare coho salmon population dynamics across a region that varies in salmon louse infestation of juvenile coho and their pink salmon prey.
Funder: Totem Flyfishers Club, a NSERC Canada Postgraduate scholarship to BMC, NSERC Canada Postdoctoral scholarship to M.K. and NSERC Canada grant A6869 to L.M.D.

Title: Lifetime success and interactions of farm salmon invading a native population
Study location: in the River Imsa, south-western Norway
Impact details: the deleterious effects of ecological and genetic interactions between farm escapees and native salmon.
Study objectives: "no study to date has quantified the life-time success (adult to adult) and interactions resulting from farm salmon invading a native population. We therefore undertook a large-scale experiment in order to simulate such an invasion of farm salmon into a Norwegian river and quantify their lifetime success and interactions with native salmon."
Methodology for data collection: 22 farm salmon and 17 native salmon  were radio tagged and experimentally released in the River Imsa,  tracked daily for 1 month. An experiment, which involved the release of 12 farm and 9 native salmon (randomly selected) into an arena designed to mimic a natural spawning environment (47 m2), was initiated in parallel with the river release. Nests excavated and live and dead eggs recorded. Offspring and lifetime reproductive success were sampled by electrofishing and genetic typing analysed. Returns of adult offspring were recorded from the coastal and river fisheries and Imsa fish traps.
Funder: Norwegian Research Council and the Norwegian Directorate for Nature Management.

Title: The salmon aquaculture conflict in British Columbia: A graph model analysis
Study location: British Columbia
Farming system: open-net pen systems, processing plants, fresh water hatcheries
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: Aquaculture stakeholders environmental concerns, sustainability of the industry practices, the cultural impacts on the coastal communities, and conflicts with other users of coastal resources.
Study objectives: "In this study, the graph model for conflict resolution has been used to model and analyze the British Columbia salmon aquaculture conflict in a way that reflects the context—the intricate ecosystem, the complex socio-economic background, and the conflicting objectives of the stakeholder"
Methodology for data collection: The decision support system GMCR II, which permits the graph model methodology to be conveniently implemented in practice, is used to model and analyze the strategic interaction of aquaculturists, environmental groups, First Nations, other stakeholders, and the provincial and federal governments

Title: Modeling Small Scale Impacts of Multi-Purpose Platforms: An Ecosystem Approach
Study country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: South west of the Isle of Muck, West coast Scotland
Farming system: Multi-Purpose Platforms (MPPs) - combined offshore windfarms and aquaculture
Impact details: Predicted ecosystem impacts of an MMP offshore system, from increasing productivity around a site due to excess feed spilling into the water column and the accumulation of sedimentary organic matter also enhancing epibenthic communities growth, as well as the attraction of wild populations of mid- and top-predators.
Impact category: Ecological > Epibenthos > Community composition, Ecological > Wild fish > Community composition
Study objectives: "Here we created a high-resolution spatiotemporal Ecospace model of the West of Scotland, in order to assess impacts of a simple MPP configuration on the surrounding ecosystem and how these impacts can cascade through the food web. The model evaluated the following specific ecosystem responses: (i) top-down control pathways due to distribution changes among top-predators (harbor porpoise, gadoids and seabirds) driven by attraction to the farming sites and/or repulsion/killing due to OWT operations; (ii) bottom-up control pathways due to salmon farm activity providing increasing benthic enrichment predicated by a fish farm particle dispersal model, and sediment nutrient fluxes to the water column by early diagenesis of organic matter (recycled production)."
Methodology for data collection: A high resolution model was built in Ecopath with Ecosim and Ecospace - the most suitable tools for evaluating the direct and indirect effects of anthropogenic pressures on spatial scale ecosystem dynamics.
Funder: Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council UK (EPSRC), the Natural Environment Research Council UK (NERC), through grant, and the Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC)

Title: Chlorophyll, lipid profiles and bioturbation in sediments around a fish cage farm in the Gulf of Eilat, Israel
Study location: The ‘Ardag’ fish farm at the northern end of the Gulf of Eilat near the Israel–Jordan border
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: differences in the benthic response to increased OM supply from fish cages of warmer oligotrophic systems
Study objectives: "Our objectives were 1) to examine sediment processes near a fish farm in a relatively poorly understood, highly oligotrophic, anti-fjordic system and 2) to compare these to results obtained earlier (Nickell et al., 2003) from a fish farm in Scotland in a well-studied, nutrient-rich fjordic system (Loch Creran, Scotland)"
Methodology for data collection: Sediment biogeochemical processes were measured on a transect of 4 stations FF 20W, 40W and 80W (number is metres from the fish farm, FF, to the west) at the Ardag gilthead seabream Sparus aurata farm in the Gulf of Aqaba, a highly oligotrophic system renowned for its clear water and diverse corals.
