At each station samples were taken for analysis of macrofaunal community and benthic oxygen demand, together with depth profiles of CHN, porosity, chlorophyll a and fatty acids and analysed.
Funder: British Council and the EU FP5 BIOFAQs project

Title: Linking salmon aquaculture synergies and trade-offs on ecosystem services to human wellbeing constituents
Study species: Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar), Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha)
Study location: 15 of the 30 municipalities of the Los Lagos region (Southern Chile (Chiloe)): Ancud, Calbuco, Castro, Chaiten, Chonchi, Cochamo ́, Curaco de Velez, Dalcahue, Hualaihue ́, Puerto Montt, Puqueldon, Quemchi, Queilen, Quinchao, and Quellon.
Farming system: open-net pen systems, processing plants, fresh water hatcheries
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: the trade-offs and decreases in local ecosystem services and its effects on human wellbeing, due to salmon aquaculture. at the local scale (municipality), ecosystem services are degrading while the human wellbeing is also declining (apart from living standards)
Study objectives: "The specific objectives of this paper are the following: (a) to identify the relationships between ecosystem services and salmon aquaculture, (b) to identify and analyse the flows of synergies and trade-offs between ecosystem services caused by the salmon aquaculture, and (c) to evaluate the trade-offs on ecosystem services associated with salmon aquaculture and its implications for human wellbeing in the social–ecological system of Chiloe"
Methodology for data collection: using a step-by-step approach - Aggregation of data on ecosystem services, use of InVEST Aesthetic model, use data proxies to determine undesirable and desirable outcomes on the whole chain of ecosystem services constituents, a data set of the most relevant human wellbeing indicators selected from the socio-economic survey CASEN of the Ministry of Social Development (2011), Face interviews, phone and e-mail surveys, modelling of Synergies and trade-offs caused by salmon aquaculture.
Funder: CONICYT-FONDECYT through the Postdoctoral Project No. 3130633, and Universidad de Los Lagos, Campus do Mar-International Campus do Mar, and the Norwegian Research Council

Title: Acute toxicity of some treatments commonly used by the salmonid aquaculture industry to Corophium volutator and Hediste diversicolor: Whole sediment bioassay tests
Study country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the)
Study location: Ythan estuary, site of Special Scientific Interest within the Forvie National Nature Reserve, Aberdeenshire, NE Scotland
Farming system: open-net pen systems, processing plants, fresh water hatcheries
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: mortality of Benthic fauna exposed to toxicities of some of the commonly applied treatments used in global salmonid aquaculture, namely the periodic application of copper-based anti-foulants and chemotherapeutic treatments,
Study objectives: "Here we present a series of whole sediment bioassay tests that determined the LC50s for the non-target benthic crustacean, C. volutator exposed to EB, OTC, AZ, CP and copper using sediments from the Ythan estuary, NE Scotland. Additional LC50 experiments with the non target polychaete worm, H. diversicolor exposed to EB- and copper-spiked Ythan sediments are also presented.
Methodology for data collection: whole sediment bioassays - Sediment, macrofauna and seawater samples collected from Ythan estuary, C. volutator were collected from the upper 5 cm of sediment through a 1 mm sieve, H. diversicolor were collected by careful hand-digging. Dosing of sediment with increasing concentrations of chemotherapeutic medicinal compound treatments, and 30 healthy C. volutator, or 6 H. diversicolor were added to each replicate core. Each experimental and control treatment was replicated five times to measure % of mortality.
Funder: Scottish Aquaculture Research Forum (SARF 009

Title: Stakeholders' perceptions of marine fish farming in Catalonia (Spain): A Q-methodology approach
Study species: Sea bass (Dicentrus labrax), Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata)
Study location: region of Catalonia, NE Spain
Impact details: negative perceptions by stakeholders towards aquaculture, based on distinct environmental, social and economic challenges that need to be overcome
Impact category: Social > Attitudes > General perceptions of aquaculture
Study objectives: "This study aims at understanding the causes for the decrease of the present fish farming sector in Catalonia and to investigate the limitations, challenges and opportunities in an environmental, social and economic context. The specific research questions were: (1) what are the distinct perceptions regarding the ecological, social and economic costs and benefits of fish farming in Catalonia, (2) which are the major areas of agreement and disagreement between perceptions, (3) which stakeholder groups share the same perception and (4) which are the most important issues and proposed measurements for improvement?
Methodology for data collection: Q-methodology was applied, consisting of collecting and selecting statements directly from stakeholders, getting stakeholders to sort the statements according to their agreement or disagreement, factor analysis of the sorts, and finally analysis and interpretation of the factors identified. Semi-structured face-to-face interviews with 35 well-informed stakeholders (included scientists, NGOs, fish farmers, fishermen and the regional fishing and aquaculture administration.) were conducted during the period from April to June 2012.
Funder: Spanish National Research Council (CSIC)

Title: The effect of a salmon cage culture on the benthic community in a largely enclosed bay (Dark Harbour, Grand Manan Island, N.B., Canada)
Study location: Dark Harbour, Grand Manan Island, New Brunswick, Canada
Impact details: Detrimental effects on benthic communities under salmon cages in enclosed shallow bay
Study objectives: "The study included bottom surveys to determine the extent of dispersal and accumulation of suspended solids, the tidal current regime, the influence of the cage system on water flow patterns, and comparisons among cage sites on the severity of benthic habitat destruction are presented."
Methodology for data collection: Samples and measures taken at multiple selected stations that reflected daily and seasonal changes 1) temperature / Salinity, 2) Water currents 3) Secchi disk readings, 4) Benthic samples by scuba diver

Title: Sea lice in the North Pacific: from sub-lethal effects on wild salmon to parasite management and policy
Study location: northern Johnstone Strait, and Discovery Islands, between Vancouver Island and the mainland of British British Columbia
Farming system: open-net pen systems, processing plants, fresh water hatcheries
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: decreased competitive ability, foraging success, growth and survival of wild juvenile sockeye salmon (O. nerka) from heavy parasitic sea lice (Lepeophtheirus salmonis and Caligus clemensi) infestation from open-net salmon farms
Impact category: Ecological > Pathogens > Sea lice, Ecological > Wild fish > Mortality
Study objectives: "This thesis examines the potential sub-lethal effects of sea lice, specifically Caligus clemensi, on wild salmon and the effectiveness of policy designed to control sea lice on salmon farms. I use British Columbia (BC), Canada as a model system and I use juvenile Fraser River sockeye as my study organism." Including: "1) the potential effects of sea lice on the competitive abilities of juvenile sockeye salmon, 2) whether that louse-associated reduction in competitive foraging ability translates to reduced foraging success in the wild, 3) evaluate whether heavily infested juvenile sockeye experience decreased growth – an important determinant of survival for salmon"
Methodology for data collection: Johnstone strait - captured 1600 juvenile sockeye by purse seine between 5 and 40 m from shore, performed Infection status assessment, recorded Infection abundances of sea lice before and after a competitive foraging experiment in an experimental facility, then dissection of stomach contents, measuring relative stomach fullness of varying levels of infected fish. Also Zooplankton sampling and analysis with a plankton tow at the fish capture site. Discovery island - 2,401 juvenile sockeye salmon were captured over 79 collections and performed sea lice assesssment and Otolith preparation and interpretation.
Funder: NSERC IPS, Watershed Watch Salmon Society, Simon Fraser University, TIDES Canada, MITACS, and the W. Garfield Weston Foundation

Title: Environmental DNA from multiple pathogens is elevated near active Atlantic salmon farms: Salmon farm elevate marine pathogen eDNA
Study location: multiple active and inactive salmon farm locations between Vancouver Island and the BC mainland
Farming system: open-net pen systems, processing plants, fresh water hatcheries
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: Active Salmon farms are associated with elevated pathogen eDNA, and may act as a source of elevated pathogens for a diverse assemblage of pathogen species, particularly 5 species of wild Pacific salmon.
Study objectives: "we use eDNA to empirically evaluate the distribution of a diverse assemblage of pathogens in the marine environment in relation to domestic salmon populations in coastal British Columbia (BC), Canada. In this system, transmission among salmonids can occur between five species of wild Pacific salmon and net-pen farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) via their shared marine environment."
Methodology for data collection: seawater sample surveys conducted in 2016 (March–April), 2017 (July–August), and 2018 (June–July) from salmon-farm tenure locations (both active (59) and inactive (75)) in southern BC. Performed laboratory sample eDNA pathogen extraction and processing, then modelled the presence of pathogen DNA as a binary variable ( present or absent) per site using a generalized linear mixed-effects model (GLMM).
Funder: David Suzuki Foundation and Ontario Graduate Scholarship, NSERC and Killam Trusts, the Liber Ero Fellowship Program to G.M., an NSERC Discovery grant to S.S., an NSERC Discovery grant, and Canada Research Chair.

Title: Environmental DNA dispersal from Atlantic salmon farms
Study location: Tribune Channel and Knight Inlet located northeast of Vancouver Island, British Columbia,
Farming system: open-net pen systems, processing plants, fresh water hatcheries
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: increased risk and the spatial extent of infectious agent spread between salmon farms and wild salmon species.
Study objectives: "In British Columbia, salmon farms operate along coastal migration routes used by five species of native Pacific salmon and rich communities of nonsalmonid fish. To help inform eDNA-based monitoring of mobile wild fish species and pathogens in this system, we empirically estimated eDNA dispersal from stationary domesticated Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) populations."
Methodology for data collection: " we evaluated the extent of Atlantic salmon eDNA dispersal in relation to 4 active salmon farms by fitting dispersal kernels to 83 estimates of Atlantic salmon eDNA concentrations from 2 and 8 m depths at 0.3–3 km intervals along a narrow 55 km channel. Using a combination of field collections, molecular analysis, and Bayesian parameter estimation model."
Funder: David Suzuki Foundation and an Ontario Graduate Scholarship, NSERC Banting Postdoctoral Fellowship, NSERC Discovery Grant and Canada Research Chair, NSERC Discovery Grant, and Fisheries and Oceans Canada Genomics Research and Development Initiative

Title: Assessing risks of invasion through gamete performance: farm Atlantic salmon sperm and eggs show equivalence in function, fertility, compatibility and competitiveness to wild Atlantic salmon
Study location: Wild and farmed fish derived from River Namsen (Norway)
Impact details: Risks of reproduction between wild Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) and escaped domesticated fish farm salmon and and subsequent introgression and genetic swamping of wild gene pools.
Study objectives: "Here, we assess reproductive performance at the gamete level through detailed in vitro comparisons of the form, function, fertility, compatibilitycompetitiveness of farm versus wild Atlantic salmon sperm and eggs, in conditions mimicking the natural gametic microenvironment, using fish raised under similar environmental conditions."
Methodology for data collection: Wild fish caught from River Namsen, farmed fish were 7th generation from Norway’s national breeding programme AquageFish, originating from River Namsen. Fish Maintenance, fertilization trials, egg rearing, Sperm trait analyses, sperm competition trials and parentage analysis using Microsatellite DNA analysis were carried out at the Norwegian Institute of Nature Research (NINA) Aquatic Research Station in Ims, Norway.
Funder: Natural Environment Research Council and the Royal Society

Title: Application of biotic and abiotic indicators for detecting benthic impacts of marine salmonid farming among coastal regions of Tasmania
Study location: 42 salmonid (salmon and trout) farms across Tasmania regions D'Entrecasteaux Channel, Huon, Macquarie Harbour, Tasman Peninsula, Tamar.
Impact details: Changes in benthic faunal assemblage composition around salmon farms which adversely impact regional biodiversity and coastal ecological processes.
Study objectives: "here we describe results from the invertebrate and sediment sampling component of a six-year period of systematic benthic monitoring, habitat condition at replicated sites (i) within farms, (ii) at compliance monitoring sites located 35 m from farm boundaries, and (iii) at more distant reference locations, by sampling benthic invertebrates and sediments at 2-year intervals. In addition to a comparative assessment of useful indicators of fish farm impacts, the present study also aimed to characterise environmental impacts of fish farms on the benthic environment across a biogeographic ‘provincial’ scale"
Methodology for data collection: triplicate macrofaunal samples were collected 5m apart at each site using either a Van Veen grab or diver operated corer pushed into the seabed to a depth of 100 mm, by four different organisations over time-series. Three replicate samples were collected on each sampling occasion at a total of 411 sites studied and analysis allowed indicators of fish farm impact with general relevance to be identified.

Title: Toward social-ecological coastal zone governance of Chiloé Island (Chile) based on the DPSIR framework
Study location: Chiloé Island
Impact details: increased coastal fisheries and aquaculture generate a critical decrease of coastal species, eutrophication, and pollution that, along with harmful algal blooms, generate social-economic conflicts.
Study objectives: "What is the main social-ecological impact of the changes in Chiloé coastal zone ecosystems? This article explores this question based on a DPSIR model, a social-ecological survey, and local experts and social actors' interviews."
Methodology for data collection: DPSIR model which was developed, (analyzing Chiloé coastal zone literature for the period 1970–2017 where changes happened as a result of salmon and mussel farming as new commercial activities), a social-ecological survey in four from a total of seven communes during January 2019, and local experts and social actors' interviews were performed.
Funder: CONICYT-Chile (Proyecto Fondecyt Regular N° 1170532)

Title: Effects of host migration, diversity and aquaculture on sea lice threats to Pacific salmon populations
Study location: Chatham Sound, Ogden Channel and Petrel Channel, British Columbia
Farming system: open-net pen systems, processing plants, fresh water hatcheries
Farming system coding: Offshore pens, Freshwater hatcheries, Processing plants
Impact details: sea lice parasite threats of salmon aquaculture to wild pink salmon populations and how host migration and diversity are important factors affecting parasite transmission in the oceans
Study objectives: "Here, we examine how host migration and diversity influence transmission of sea lice (the salmonid-specific Lepeophtheirus salmonis and the generalist Caligus clemensi ) in the early marine life of one of Canada’s largest salmon stocks—Skeena River pink salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha)"
Methodology for data collection: collected 21448 juvenile salmon using a dip net or an Ocean Fish Lift trawl at different times in the season, in a laboratory assayed for sea lice using a dissecting microscope. "Differences in sea lice abundance over time and between species were tested using generalized linear models with Poisson error."
Funder: Bill Shostak Wildlife Award; a Natural Science and Engineering Research Council Canada Graduate Scholarship; a Canada Research Chair and grants from the National Geographic Society, the David Suzuki Foundation, the Canadian Sablefish Association, the Canadian National Research Council’s Mathematics of Information Technology and Complex Systems program, the British Columbia Pacific Salmon Forum and the British Columbia Aquaculture Research and Development Council

Title: "There are more vets than doctors in Chiloé": social and community impact of the globalization of aquaculture in Chile
Study location: Eight communities on Isla Grande Chiloe in Southern Chile
Impact details: negative impacts on the social-economic and welfare of communities near to salmon farms
Study objectives: "This paper explores some of the complexities associated with globalization within the specific context of salmon farming in southern Chile. The central question is whether the high levels of foreign investment typical to Chile and exponential growth in the industry, have had a positive or negative impact on the people and communities of the archipelago of Chiloe"
Methodology for data collection: conducted both semi-structured interviews and focus group interviews with women's organizations, indigenous groups, salmon farm workers, processing workers, technicians and supervisors, fishers, and artisan aquaculturists. Also conducted key informant interviews with a trade union organizer, a number of community development workers, municipal and provincial government officials, and industry and research agency representatives.
Funder: AquaNet, a Network of Centers of Excellence based at Memorial University of Newfoundland, and from Saint Mary's University and Dalhousie University

Title: Salmon aquaculture and antimicrobial resistance in the marine environment
Study location: Calbuco Archipelago in southern Chile
Impact details: aquaculture activities alter concentrations of culturable bacteria in marine sediments and increase the proportion of antimicrobial-resistant bacteria, with negative impacts on marine environmental biodiversity
Study objectives: "We compared numbers of culturable bacteria and antimicrobial resistant bacteria for three antimicrobials used extensively in Chilean salmon aquaculture (oxytetracycline, oxolinic acid, and florfenicol) in the marine sediment adjacent to salmon aquaculture pens and at a control site 8 km distant with no observed aquaculture or other human activities."
Methodology for data collection: Sediment samples taken by scuba divers using 15 cm diameter PVC plastic core samplers, performed seven times at each site over a 12 month period, 33 samples from the aquaculture site and 33 samples from the control site. Samples tested for presence of; Antimicrobials, Culturable bacteria, Antimicrobial-resistant bacteria, antimicrobial resistance genes in bacteria and Species identification of bacteria harboring antimicrobial resistance genes - through RNA gene sequence analysis
Funder: Lenfest Ocean Program / Pew Charitable Trusts

Title: Impact of salmon farming in the antibiotic resistance and structure of marine bacterial communities from surface seawater of a northern Patagonian area of Chile
Study location: Chiloe Island, Southern Chile
Impact details: increased association between bacterial communities and antibiotic resistance around Salmon farms
Study objectives: "Here, we evaluated whether the structure and diversity of marine bacterial community, the richness of antibiotic resistance bacteria and the frequency of antibiotic resistance genes increase in communities from the surface seawater of an area with salmon farming activities, in comparison with communities from an area without major anthropogenic disturbance"
Methodology for data collection: Seawater samples taken at an aquaculture and control site with different sampling points from each site to create replicates. Samples investigated the genetic determinants of antibiotic resistance by shotgun sequencing of marine bacterial communities and the phenotypic resistance of the communities by growing the culturable fraction under controlled laboratory conditions.
Funder: ANID grants Fondecyt 1211893 (VC), Millennium Science Initiative Program – ICN2021_044, and Subvención a la Instalación en la Academia SA77210039 (JOS)

Title: Prevalence and survival of escaped European seabass Dicentrarchus labrax in Cyprus identified using genetic markers
Study location: Multiple areas around southern coast of Cyprus
Impact details: Presence of genetically identified farmed seabass escapees in the wild population
Study objectives: "The present study is one of the first studies to quantify the prevalence of escaped European seabass in the wild using microsatellite markers. With the comprehensive sampling of aquaculture and wild sources around the island we set out to provide a robust estimate of the potential impact of seabass escapes on native populations that is applicable to the aquaculture industry as a whole. Our study is also the most extensive genetic study of Cypriot seabass populations, characterising both aquaculture and native stocks for the first time"
Methodology for data collection: 994 European seabass samples were collected for genetic analysis, and the types and sources, collected from 5 sampling areas in the wild (caught by fisherman using nets, rod and line and spearfishing), and 3 aquaculture facilities from hatchery broodstock. All samples were subject to DNA Molecular analysis.
Funder: Cyprus Research Promotion Foundation and the Republic of Cyprus and the EU Regional Development Fund

Title: Biogeochemical observations to assess benthic impacts of organic enrichment from marine aquaculture in the Western Isles region of the Bay of Fundy, 1994
Study location: Letang Inlet, Passamaquoddy Bay, Deer Island, Campobello Island, Beaver Harbour, and Deadman's Harbour, in the Western Isles region of Bay of Fundy, Canada
Impact details: macrofauna benthic impacts of net-pen aquaculture
Study objectives: "The present report adds to this growing base of marine environmental information in the Western Isles region by comparing different methods that may be used to assess changes in geotechnical, geochemical, and biological properties in subtidal sediment under salmon aquaculture sites. The data can be used to assess the degree of sensitivity of different variables to detect benthic impacts of net-pen aquaculture at different sites."
Methodology for data collection: macrofauna biomass was collected and measured using a Hunter grab by a diver at 22 stations, 11 sites under salmon net-pens, and 11 control stations located >50 m from these sites (5 grabs at each station)

Title: Spatial dissimilarity of zooplankton and hydrodynamic conditions in a Patagonian channel used intensely by aquaculture: the influence of a geomorphological constriction
Study location: Caucahué Channel (Chiloé Island, southern Chile)
Impact details: differences in community zooplankton abundance related to aquaculture farms (mussels and Salmon)
Study objectives: "The aim of this study was to assess the interaction between zooplankton distribution and hydrodynamics in Caucahué Channel, which is an area intensely used by aquaculture activities. Thus we (i) characterize the zooplankton community distribution, water column characteristics and their relationship during a short time period (hours), (ii) characterize the hydrodynamics of the channel during two fortnightly tidal cycles, and (iii) integrate information about the spatial distribution of the zooplankton community and environmental variables in neap and spring tidal cycles.
Methodology for data collection: Intensive zooplankton and water column sampling (time scale: 12 h) was carried out, together with current measurements as a background of the channel hydrodynamics (time scale: 30 days). Samples collected in 20 sites, Six sites were located near aquaculture farms (5- 50 m from the limits of the farms) and 14 sites were located far from active aquaculture farms (control sites).
Funder: Interdisciplinary Center for Aquaculture Research, INCAR (ANID; FONDAP 15110027)
